pageMeta.title: Environment at a Glance TEST
pageMeta.description: Emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) from human activities disturb the radiative energy balance of the earth-atmosphere system. They exacerbate the natural greenhouse effect, leading to temperature changes and other disruption of the earth's climate. Land use changes and forestry also play a role by altering the amount of greenhouse gases captured or released by carbon sinks

book.description: Emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) from human activities disturb the radiative energy balance of the earth-atmosphere system. They exacerbate the natural greenhouse effect, leading to temperature changes and other disruption of the earth's climate. Land use changes and forestry also play a role by altering the amount of greenhouse gases captured or released by carbon sinks

content.value: is a crucial shared resource of the region, with all but two countries sharing coastlines with the Atlantic Ocean, the Pacific Ocean or the Caribbean Sea. Twenty-three of the 33 LAC countries have more marine than terrestrial territory, for 18 of which the maritime area exceeds 75% of total territory (ECLAC, 2020). Marine biodiversity sustains life in the ocean and life on land and provides critical ecosystem services like food and oxygen production, and carbon sequestration. Containing the most marine ecoregions around the world, the importance of oceans to the health of the environment and the economic activities it supports cannot be understated.

Biodiversity loss reduces the ability of marine ecosystems to provide these services and their capacity to recover from climatic or biogeochemical changes. Ocean-related industries have expanded with insufficient consideration for the environment, risking the natural resources and essential marine ecosystem services on which economies and the well-being of people depend.
well-being of people and the resilience of coastal communities to risks

. Sea level rise, extreme weather events, over-extraction of marine resources, over-tourism, and air and water pollution from ocean industries and land-based sources can threaten the health, infrastructure and livelihoods of coastal populations living across the majority of Latin America and the Caribbean.
The main challenge is to ensure
the goals of oceans are not left behind.

The only international target that was met by 2020 was the Sustainable Development Goal 14.5, prescribing the designation of at least 10% of marine areas under protection. The socio-ecological importance of oceans means that adequate monitoring of such goals is crucial, prioritising the development of region-specific policies such as sustainable fishing with special attention to small scale fisheries, pollution and priority ecosystems as mangroves (ECLAC, 2020).

Another important challenge is to adapt coastal communities to the risks stemming from rising sea levels, extreme weather events and other natural hazards, and the consequent primary and secondary effects. As appropriate for local contexts, countries should engage with and protect those most vulnerable, adopt long-term plans for coastal areas which take future changes into account, implement maritime spatial planning in coherence with coastal zone management, and protect existing coastal ecosystems that serve as natural buffers.
Environmental performance can be assessed against domestic objectives and international goals and commitments.
is an integral part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development (New York, September 2015)
“Conserve and sustainably use the oceans, seas and marine resources for sustainable development”.
The main international agreement on biodiversity is the 1992 Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD). The CBD held its 15

Conference of the Parties (COP15) in Montreal from 7-19 December 2022, where the Post-2020 Biodiversity Framework was discussed, comprising 21 targets and 10 ‘milestones’ proposed for 2030. Notable targets include the designation of at least 30% of Earth’s land and sea areas as protected for conservation; the reduction of nutrients lost to the environment by at least half, pesticides by at least two thirds, and the elimination of discharge of plastic waste; and the reduction of harmful incentives for biodiversity by at least 50 billion USD per year. Positively, several Latin American and Caribbean countries comply with the protected areas target. Work remains to be done for other targets such as plastic waste, which is predicted to increase by 30% from 2019 to 2030.

The United Nations Climate Change Conference COP27 held in Sharm el-Sheikh from 6-18 November 2022 closed with the establishment of a Loss and Damage fund for countries vulnerable to arising from droughts, floods, rising sea level and other disasters attributed to climate change being particularly relevant for the Caribbean islands. At the time of writing, no decision has been reached on the sources or recipients of said funding.
Population resident within 10 km of coast as share of total population

Note: These counts use a definition of coastal based on distance (as opposed to travel time or some socioeconomic concept of coastalness). Obviously such areas do not necessarily have any close physical access to the sea or any cultural or economic connection. Conversely, areas well inland but with (e.g.) river ports may have economic or coastal links (and exposure to coastal risks) but are not counted.
Coastlines are inherently ‘fuzzy’ concepts and results calculated using them are likely to be sensitive to the specific coastal boundaries used.
Source: OECD, “Sustainable Ocean Economy”, OECD Environment Statistics (database),
Population resident within 100 km of coast as share of total population

Note: These counts use a definition of coastal based on distance (as opposed to travel time or some socioeconomic concept of coastalness). Obviously such areas do not necessarily have any close physical access to the sea or any cultural or economic connection. Conversely, areas well inland but with (e.g.) river ports may have economic or coastal links (and exposure to coastal risks) but are not counted.
Coastlines are inherently ‘fuzzy’ concepts and results calculated using them are likely to be sensitive to the specific coastal boundaries used.
Source: OECD, “Sustainable Ocean Economy”, OECD Environment Statistics (database),

Marine protected areas are less commonly present than terrestrial protected areas throughout the LAC region, with Chile being the only country reaching the CBD 2030 target calling for 30% of the sea territory to be under protection. While the dependent territories of Guadeloupe, Martinique, Saint Barthelemy and Saint Martin also reach the 2030 CBD target, this is only through the high proportion of protected seascapes, the least stringent degree of protection, or areas with no management category provided. As with terrestrial protected areas, there is large scope for improvement, as only 10 territories have strict nature reserves, national parks or wilderness areas, all of which do not reach the CBD 2030 target. The share of marine protected areas across the region has increased slowly from 1960, remaining below 3% of the exclusive economic zone area until 2010, and below 5% until 2016.

Marine protected areas as percentage of exclusive economic zone (EEZ): protected areas are areas of sea especially dedicated to the protection and maintenance of biological diversity and of natural and associated cultural resources, and managed through legal or other effective means. The data refer to the World Conservation Union (IUCN) management categories I-VI. National classifications may differ.

Note: the the Global Biodiversity Framework establishes the “30x30” conservation target, calling for 30% of the earth’s land and sea to be conserved through the establishment of protected areas and other area-based conservation measures.
Source: OECD, “Biodiversity: Protected areas”, OECD Environment Statistics (database),

Data on protected areas is available for most LAC countries. The definitions, although harmonised by the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, may vary among countries. The extent, and management types, of terrestrial and marine protected areas can indicate countries’ efforts to safeguard habitats and species as well as landscapes shaped by human-environment interactions that are valued for cultural or other reasons. Protected areas are not always representative of national biodiversity or sufficiently connected. Indicators on the extent of protected areas do not reflect the effectiveness of the management of these areas.
